channel.title: BBC News | News Front Page | UK Edition
channel.description: Updated every minute of every day - FOR PERSONAL USE ONLY

item.title: Treasury 'holds back' ERM papers
item.description: The Treasury is to hold back paperwork relating to Black Wednesday 1992, the BBC has learned.

item.title: Palestinian groups disown truce
item.description: Hamas and Islamic Jihad say they are not bound by the Palestinian truce agreed with Israel in Egypt.

item.title: New Iraqi abuse charge dropped
item.description: A judge tells a court martial panel to clear a soldier of a charge of pretending to kick an Iraqi prisoner in Basra.

item.title: Bomb accused hope for apology
item.description: Members of two families wrongly jailed over IRA bomb attacks in the 1970s are hoping Tony Blair will publicly apologise.

item.title: Man in court over Omagh bomb
item.description: A man will appear in court charged with providing the car used in the Omagh bomb which killed 29 people in 1998.

item.title: 'Eta car bomb' explodes in Madrid
item.description: A suspected Eta car bomb explodes near a conference centre in Madrid, injuring at least 27 people.

item.title: Scammers compile 'suckers' lists
item.description: Consumers are warned they could be put on a "suckers" list if they respond to unlikely offers promising money.

item.title: MPs set for EU constitution clash
item.description: Laws to pave the way to a referendum on the EU constitution are to be debated by MPs.

item.title: Sport betting rules in spotlight
item.description: An all-party group of MPs and peers is expected to call for tighter regulations controlling betting on sport.

item.title: Police investigate Glazer threats
item.description: Police will probe threats made by a militant group of Man Utd fans against Malcolm Glazer proposed takeover.

item.title: Cricket: Fletcher stays on
item.description: England coach Duncan Fletcher dismisses rumours that he is interested in the South Africa post.

item.title: Football: Eriksson's Rooney worry
item.description: Sven-Goran Eriksson will talk to Wayne Rooney about his temperament ahead of the game against Holland.

item.title: Emergency summit over Togo crisis
item.description: West Africa's regional body, Ecowas, is to meet in Niger to discuss the deepening political crisis in Togo.

item.title: Football clash for Asian rivals
item.description: Japan and North Korea kick off a key football match, overshadowed by heightened political tensions.

item.title: Top US team presses Nato on Iraq
item.description: Condoleezza Rice and Donald Rumsfeld lead a two-pronged drive to revive US relations with its European allies.

item.title: Ailing Pope to miss Lent service
item.description: Ailing Pope John Paul II is to miss Ash Wednesday services for the first time in his 26 years as pontiff.

item.title: Rice warns Iran of UN sanctions
item.description: US Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice warns Iran of possible UN action over its suspected nuclear activities.

item.title: DNA test on disputed tsunami baby
item.description: DNA samples are taken from Sri Lankan tsunami survivor "Baby 81" and the couple who claim him as their own.

item.title: Shipman pharmacist faces action
item.description: A pharmacist criticised for failing to spot Harold Shipman's unusual prescription habits is facing a disciplinary hearing.

item.title: Pensioner injured during robbery
item.description: An 82-year-old woman is recovering in hospital after being robbed by a gang at her home in County Down.

item.title: Device to save premature babies
item.description: A cot-side device could save the lives of thousands of premature babies, say doctors.

item.title: Swansea leisure centre to reopen
item.description: More than a year after it was closed down, £25m is to be spent to reopen Swansea Leisure Centre.

item.title: Euronext trumpets LSE bid savings
item.description: European stock market operator Euronext outlines details of its proposed bid for the London Stock Exchange - but puts no value on any offer.

item.title: Asylum children to face returns
item.description: Ministers are planning to return unaccompanied child asylum seekers to Albania, under a trial scheme.

item.title: Concerns over lung patient deaths
item.description: More than one in 10 patients admitted to hospital with a serious respiratory disorder is dead within 90 days, a study finds.

item.title: Children 'lack web safety advice'
item.description: Almost a third of UK children have not had lessons on how to use the internet safely, a report suggests.

item.title: Call for £100m UK stem cell fund
item.description: Scientists and entrepreneurs call for the creation of a charitable foundation to promote and fund UK stem cell research.

item.title: Consumer concern over RFID tags
item.description: Consumers are very concerned about the use of radio frequency ID (RFID) tags in shops, a survey shows.

item.title: Stars prepare for 25th Brit bash
item.description: Brits nominees Franz Ferdinand are set to join some of the music world's biggest names at the 25th awards.

item.title: Scams: Your experiences
item.description: A campaign to help people identify scams is being launched by the Office of Fair Trading. Have you been a scam victim?
